Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Okay, Im trying to figure out which cases in the event log deviate from the normative process described. Let me go through each case one by one to see if they follow the correct sequence.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Starting with Case 1. The activities are Receive order, Check inventory, Authorize payment, Package items, Ship order, Close order. That looks exactly like the ideal flow when inventory is sufficient. So Case 1 seems fine.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now, Case 2. The activities are Receive, Check inventory, Package items, Authorize payment, Ship, Close. Wait, after Check inventory, it goes to Package items, then Authorize payment. But according to the normative process, after checking inventory, if its sufficient, the next step should be Authorize payment, then Package, then Ship. So in Case 2, Packaging happens before Authorization, which is out of order. Thats a violation because payment should be authorized before packaging.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Moving on to Case 3. The sequence is Receive, Check inventory, Authorize payment, Cancel order, Ship, Close. After Authorize payment, it goes to Cancel order. But the normative process says that if inventory is insufficient, after Check inventory, it should go directly to Cancel, then Close. Also, after Cancel, you shouldnt proceed to Ship. So here, after Cancel, its trying to Ship, which doesnt make sense. So two violations here: shipping after cancellation and not closing immediately after cancellation.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Case 4 is Receive, Check inventory, Cancel order, Close order. Thats the correct sequence when inventory is insufficient. It goes from Check to Cancel to Close, which is exactly what the normative process outlines. So Case 4 is fine.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Case 5 has Receive, Check inventory, Authorize payment, Ship order, Close. Wait, after Authorize payment, it goes directly to Ship without Packaging items. The normative process says that after Authorization, you should Package, then Ship. So missing the Package step is a violation.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So summarizing the issues: Case 2: Packaging before Authorization. Case 3: Shipping after Cancellation and not closing after Cancellation. Case 5: Shipping without Packaging. I think thats all the deviations. Each of these cases breaks the sequence set by the normative process as described.
